paragraph: “Onward, hasten;           Turn to the East.·    ·    ·    ·    ·O woman, thou cherishest           The sublimest hero of the world           In thy sheltering womb.”The motive of dismemberment is found again in the broken sword of Siegmund, which was kept for Siegfried. From the dismemberment life is pieced together again. (The Medea wonder.) Just as a smith forges the pieces together, so is the dismembered dead again put together. (This comparison is also found in “Timaios” of Plato: the parts of the world joined together with pegs.) In the Rigveda, 10, 72, the creator of the world, Brahmanaspati, is a smith.“Brahmanaspati, as a blacksmith,           Welded the world together.”The sword has the significance of the phallic sun power; therefore, a sword proceeds from the mouth of the apocalyptic Christ; that is to say, the procreative fire, the word, or the procreative Logos. In Rigveda, Brahmanaspati is also a prayer-word, which possessed an ancient creative significance:[697]“And this prayer of the singers, expanding from itself,     Became a cow, which was already there before the world,     Dwelling together in the womb of this god,     Foster-children of the same keeper are the gods.”—_Rigveda_ x: 31.
question: How is the sword metaphorically linked to phallic and solar concepts, and what does this imply about its source?
answer: The sword is metaphorically linked to phallic and solar concepts, symbolizing the procreative and life-giving power. This is evident in the idea that a sword emerges from the mouth of the apocalyptic Christ, representing the procreative fire, word, or procreative Logos. This metaphor suggests that the sword, as a symbol of power and creation, originates from a source of life and divine energy.
